												I don't have alot of playtime on this game, but I'll try to go through it properly.First of, I loved Rebuild 1 and 2. When I heard there was a third game coming up, I was excited. When I heard it was going to cost? No so much, but I decided to give it a go, if only to support the devs for their two previous games. I expected it to be at least as great as Rebuild 2. My opinion? Deadsville is far, far greater, and worth every penny. Now to the review itself.Let's begin with the zombies. What's a zombie game without zombies, eh?In Rebuild 1 and 2, zombies surrounded your fort all the time. They could attack out of nowhere, anytime, and the risk of injuries/areas of the fort depended on the surrounding zombies - the defense of the fort, which was survivors on duty/idling + some buildings like marts and police stations.In Deadsville, the zombies still surround your fort. But here, they can only attack once they have "massed", similiar to a Zombie Horde, which will be marked on a location around your fort. They won't attack as soon as they're formed, but you will need to station some to prepare once they have. You can also attack the massed zombies if you have the strenght for it, but it's generally a better idea to wait for them to come to you.Zombie Hordes are still in this game, fullfilling the same purpose like in Rebuild 1 and 2, and just like with "massed" zombies, you can attack them instead of waiting for them, but you REALLY should wait for them to attack instead, much safer that way.Now, let's talk about survivors.In Rebuild 1 and 2, you'd have alot of survivors. You generally didn't bother remember their names or faces, since you'd eventually have too many at once. There would be so many to recruit, that if 4-5 died, you wouldn't give a damn.In Deadsville, you have slightly fewer survivors, but they feel abit more important and personal. You most likely won't see 12-16 surrounding your fort at once, so each one you see will give you the feeling "I have to recruit him/her".Also, now you will see where they are and what they are doing, similarly to how you could see where the Zombie Horde was in Rebuild 1 and 2, in the form of a marker. Placing a survivor in the fort randomly will NOT add to it's defense. Instead, you must place survivors inside the fort next to zombies markers, so they will defend the fort once the zombies decide to attack.Next: factions. You remember the Riffs, the Last Judgement Gang and Gustav? They're all here and more, each their own faction.In Rebuild 1 and 2, the Riffs, LJG and Gustav where all events that happened, the Riffs killing zombies randomly, the LJG trying to attack/rob you, and Gustav appearing to trade among other things.In Deadsville, the three mentioned above have returned, with a few other, newer groups, and they all have forts on their own (I'm unsure about Gustav, I think he's a nomad(wandering trader)). You can either ignore them, trade with them, ally with them or destroy them. Destroying is dangerous, obviously, but it's faster should you have alot of trained soldier-survivors. Allying takes time, but it's safer, if a bit costly, but it will be more worth it in the long run.Almost at the end are we? Let's look at resources.In Rebuild 1 and 2, there was food and happiness. Few and Simple.In Rebuild 3, there's those two and materials, ammunition, medicine and fuel. Materials is used in building barricades (that is, expanding your fort.) or re-building a useless building to something... well, usefull. You can get more materials by scavenging, trading, destroying a building or chopping wood(will be explained later).Ammunition is pretty self-explanatory isn't it? It's used during events (mostly defense where you more than 0% danger) or if your survivor is equipped with a gun and uses it while attacking/defending. It can be acquired by scavenging, trading or crafting (will be explained later)Medicine and fuel is used mainly in events, and can be acquired through scavenging and trades, and used in events and trades.Finally, let's talk about Survivor Classes.In Rebuild 1 and 2, there were Soldiers, Scavengers, Researchers, Builders and Leaders, each with their own, obvious purpose. In Rebuild 2, you could train each and everyone in all the fields, making them all-around epic units (jack of all trades and master of all).In Rebuild 3, Researchers have become Engineers. They still research mind you, but they, like the others, fulfill more than just one purpose. In the Engineers case, they also "manafacture" items, ammo and more, depending on how much you have researched.Soldiers I think hasn't changed any.Scavengers were pretty damn useless after early game, when you got food through farms, when your survivors had maxed stats so giving them items were pointless, so that all they could do was sit around or help out with the fighting. Now, they have two new reasons to live. First is hunting. On some specific places, there are "fields" where wild animals live. You can send a scout to "hunt" regardless if the field is in your fort or not, to acquire food. Like farming, bartering etc, this is a "endless" job that only ends if a Zombie Horde gets too close, or you tell the Scavenger to come back. Second is stealing. As said earlier, there are factions with their own forts. A Scavenger can be ordered to steal from them, the greater his scavenging ability, the more likely he is to succeed. Do note that the faction will like you less (duh).Builders have changed alot aswell. They, too, have two new reasons to live aside from expanding the fort and re-building usless stuff. First is chopping wood. You know materials? Send a builder to a forest or a place with trees in general, and he will go on an "endless" mission to get more materials. The higher his builder-level, the more he will get each day.Second is farming. Yes, farming. Anyone can farm, but a builder nets a greater result.Leaders helped recruit new survivors. Well, now they also hang out in the bar or church for the sake of increasing happiness or talk with other factions.Firstly, they can be stationed "endlessly" in a bar or church to increase happiness in the fort, just like in Rebuild 1 and 2. Exactly how it works I'm unsure of in Deadsville, since I've stationed a level 10 leader in a church to "preach" but happiness wasn't visibly affected...Secondly, sending an experienced leader to another faction will make it easier to befriend them (you may find out if they need something, or get better options when talking with them (for example, one faction wanted 5 traps, but my leader was high level enough so he could convince them 1 was enough))There are also alot of events surrounding your survivors, which can grant them various perks, but I won't go into that. Don't want to spoil the fun now, eh?All in all, it's a great game. If you enjoyed Rebuild 1 and 2, you can and WILL enjoy this.
